text.section: Commission staff shall be responsible for directing and conducting investigations of discrimination and retaliation complaints filed under this title in a manner consistent with §§ 20-208, 20-1005, 20-1006, 20-1008, 20-1009, and 20-1010 of the State Government Article.
The Commission may request assignment of additional State personnel or outside consultants as may be reasonably necessary or appropriate to conduct an investigation.

section.section: Commission staff shall exercise reasonable judgment in seeking relevant evidence from the complainant, the respondent business entity and, as necessary, external sources.

This title may not be construed to require the State to fund the cost of:
having State staff or other individuals travel outside the State to investigate any claim under this title; or
having witnesses travel to the State for the purpose of investigating a claim or testifying at a hearing or proceeding under this title.

Consistent with § 20-1101 of the State Government Article, the Public Information Act, and the Open Meetings Act, the Commission shall protect the confidential character of information relating to an investigation and may issue protective orders for good cause to limit, or otherwise impose conditions on, access by any person to any document in the possession of a party.

A protective order issued under paragraph (1) of this subsection may include:
a document in the possession of the State or otherwise in the record that is not a public record; and
information disclosed in accordance with § 19-116 of this title.

text.section: The Commission shall exercise reasonable discretion in determining the extent of the investigation required to support Commission staff's initial findings and recommendations.

section.section:
The Commission may investigate and adjudicate a claim of discrimination under this title only if the claim alleges that:
the discrimination was committed by a business entity within the limitations period set forth in § 19-101(c) of this title; and
the discrimination occurred in the State.

Discrimination is deemed to have occurred in the State only if:
each party operated a place of business in, or resided in, the State at the time of the discrimination; or
the discriminatory act was committed in the State.
